subject: An application for hypervisor network configuration
commitMessage:
An application for hypervisor network configuration

This application takes care of hypervisor network configuration
by communicating with the bios-settings-mgr in the backend.

It hosts xyz.openbmc_project.Network.Hypervisor.service similar
to that of network service and implements system config, ethernet
and ip interfaces whose properties are mapped to the appropriate
properties in the base bios table.

The flow will be like:
- User fires the redfish command to update hypervisor
network configuration properties
- BMCWeb updates the properties in the dbus object
hosted by this application
- This application would update these new values in
the base bios table

This is divided into multiple commits and this commit
hosts xyz.openbmc_project.Network.Hypervisor.service and
creates the /xyz/openbmc_project/network/hypervisor object.

Tested By:

busctl tree xyz.openbmc_project.Network.Hypervisor
└─/xyz
  └─/xyz/openbmc_project
    └─/xyz/openbmc_project/network
      └─/xyz/openbmc_project/network/hypervisor

Signed-off-by: Asmitha Karunanithi <asmitk01@in.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I2d4582bc9c1dbf72c9963f3e43169b695b34b1ed

I did not understand why do we need old ip address?

Old ip address is needed in case if the ip address gets changed in the bios table.
If there is a change in ip, the old ip address will be deleted in the local copy of "ipaddress, ipaddress obj" map (addrs) and new ip address will be emplaced.

this should be completely ibm specific functionality. does oem-ibm makes sense ? do you see any other companies using it ?

This is an app to manage the hypervisor network configurations.

Basically an intermediate application to communicate with the hypervisor via the bios config manager. 
IBM has implemented the hypervisor ethernet interface configuration. This app is to handle those settings via bmc.

Systems that need their hypervisor / hosts to get configured with separate interfaces can use this app.
The hypervisor is already modelled as a ComputerSystem. This need not be an OEM implementation.

Anyone wanting to use this app can enable this flag, provided they must be using the appropriate bios attribute names (vmi_ is the prefix in this case, as per the changes).

> Anyone wanting to use this app can enable this flag, provided they must be using the appropriate bios attribute names (vmi_ is the prefix in this case, as per the changes).

This is what makes me think it is oem-ibm, why are we dictating requirements to other systems(non-IBM) that their bios attributes needs to be in a certain way ? i still dont feel that it is a generic code which can be leveraged by other companies.


But i would leave this call to the maintainers of this repository.
what about enum attributes ?

Till now, the enum values are treated the same way as string. So this method will be called appropriately. This is called at one place (where an ip address updation is done) in the third commit in this commit chain.

It doesn't have any additional dependencies, so you should just make it a boolean. I'd think we would want this to default to `true` so that we know via CI and use builds whether or not the code compiles. We can make it a packageconfig option in the bitbake build and exclude it in the default option set.

> It doesn't have any additional dependencies, so you should just make it a boolean.
Ack

> I'd think we would want this to default to `true`
But since this is something IBM-specific, do you think we should default it to true?

For the sake of the build I would like to make sure it continues building when going through CI. Otherwise we can make commits that will break builds for say `witherspoon` when they try to get SRCREV bumped. If we leave it default enabled then we will have better build coverage in CI. We can setup the recipe so that it doesn't get built for other machines in bitbake.
Done

William, what is your view?

This was one of the discussions we had earlier.
Either this code needs to be generic for others to use else put it under company specific flag.
We went with the latter..
Asmitha, I was thinking if we can make it generic and others can also use it by making the changes in the yaml.
Just a suggestion, Can we give some descriptive name for all the types? It improves readability.
Ack
